page.title: 15Sharnbrook's Soil & Trees
page.content: The soils in this area vary from free draining{alluvial soils}alongside the Ouse and the Sharn Brook, to{heavy {clay}overlying Oxford and Boulder clay on the higher ground. {River gravels are under the soil in the valley bottoms, which are well drained, but with water readily available near the surface. Although{most of the area's {trees have been planted,}a natural pattern is reflected in the species chosen, with{alder, willow and poplar alongside the river and brook. Heavier soils have been planted with {ash and some oak. Field maple}occurs as an understorey with{hazel and thorn as a shrub layer in the woods on the clay soils. Scattered areas of conifers, mainly{pine and spruce,}pure and in mixtures with broadleaves are not very successful on heavy soil in this low rainfall area.
